REDCapTidieR 0.0.0.9000

REDCapTidieR

REDCap is a powerful database solution used by many research institutions:

‚ÄúREDCap is a secure web application for building and managing online surveys and databases. While REDCap can be used to collect virtually any type of data in any environment (including compliance with 21 CFR Part 11, FISMA, HIPAA, and GDPR), it is specifically geared to support online and offline data capture for research studies and operations.‚Äù

The goal of REDCapTidieR is to provide users with a simple API for extracting REDCap databases and turning them into tidy tibbles. This makes for easily joinable tables with only the data necessary for specific REDCap forms, instead of the singular complex table typically received from a single export.

REDCapTidieR will be of great use to any databases using:

  • Repeating Instruments
  • Longitudinal Events
  • Longitudinal Arms

Much of the inspiration for this package is derived from the wonderful work done in the REDCapR package.

Installation

You can install the development version of REDCapTidieR like so:

devtools::install_github("CHOP-CGTDataOps/REDCapTidieR")

Examples

üöß Under Development üöß

Using the main function is simple and only requires a REDCap URI and an API token with read/write privileges:

redcap_export <- read_redcap_tidy(redcap_uri, token)

Where a sample output containing repeating instruments may look like:

redcap_export
# A tibble: 3 √ó 3
  redcap_form_name redcap_data  structure   
  <chr>            <list>       <chr>       
1 repeated         <df [9 √ó 6]> repeating   
2 nonrepeated      <df [8 √ó 5]> nonrepeating
3 nonrepeated2     <df [3 √ó 5]> nonrepeating

Where the contents of redcap_data contain only the data associated with the form:

redcap_export$redcap_data %>% pluck(1)
  record_id redcap_repeat_instance redcap_event redcap_arm repeat_1 repeat_2
1         1                      1      event_1          1        1        2
2         1                      2      event_1          1        3        4
3         1                      3      event_1          1        5        6
4         1                      1      event_2          1        A        B
5         1                      2      event_2          1        C        D
6         3                      1      event_1          1        C        D
7         3                      1      event_2          1        E        F
8         3                      2      event_2          1        G        H
9         4                      1      event_3          2       R1       R2
